Award.AwardTitle: Studies of Higgs Boson Properties and Search for New Physics with ATLAS
Award.AbstractNarration:
Overview: A goal of experiments at the Large Hadron Collider (the LHC) at CERN, Geneva, Switzerland is to understand the nature of the Higgs Boson, recently discovered there in 2012, and to discover new physics beyond the Standard Model of Elementary Particle Physics. These goals are relevant to the understanding of the Universe at its most fundamental level just in the fleeting fraction of a second just after the Big Bang, and to why we see the Universe as we do now. To meet the challenges of this quest, new theories are advanced, new detectors and accelerators are developed and built, and new computing and analytical methodologies are created, all of which have significant broader impact for the training of young scientists in the near term and the advancement of technological benefits to society over the longer term.

Broader Impact: The emphasis here is on the involvement of undergraduate students directly into the research program. The student will work directly on physics analysis and visit the CERN laboratory. One of the highlights will be the development by the students of an undergraduate research journal at Manhattan College, a potentially exciting means to develop interest and enthusiasm among the students for scientific research.

The next three years represent a transition of the LHC physics program from a collision energy of 8 TeV data-taking and operation, to extended operations and data taking at nearly double the energy, 13-14 TeV. Over a thousand scientists from the United States are involved with this scientific program on several major experiments.

Intellectual Merit: The research to be conducted under this award to Prof Konoplich and his group at Manhattan College is aimed to address deep questions about the nature of the Universe from data collected with the ATLAS experiment, one of the major multipurpose detectors at the LHC. Scientific questions addressed include: is the newly discovered Higgs particle simply the Higgs of the Standard Model or is it part of a larger theoretical picture that includes new particles that could be discovered at the new higher LHC collision energy? What are the detailed properties of this particle? Why is the observed mass of the Higgs boson so low, found to be 126 billion electron volts, or roughly 135 times the mass of the proton? In fact this low mass value is one of the most profound conundrums in all of science and is currently driving much of the scientific discourse in the field of particle physics. These questions are critical to our understanding of the full context of the Standard Model of particle physics and to new physics that lies beyond the Standard Model.

Technically, Konoplich and his group will be collaborating with colleagues at New York University and others in developing and refining the trigger for the ATLAS experiment, and notably the missing energy trigger, which is important for allowing the experiment to be sensitive to new physics. Such a development will be tactically important as the energy and the luminosity (the instantaneous collision rate) of the LHC are increased to meet the demands of the ATLAS program of discovery physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The excellent performances of the Large Hadron Collider and its detectors, and the skill and the commitment of the whole LHC team, made possible the discovery of the Higgs boson by the ATLAS and CMS collaborations. In order to prove that the discovered particle is indeed the Higgs boson responsible for the mechanism of the electroweak symmetry breaking and the mass generation of elementary particles, its quantum numbers should be determined and couplings to other particles measured. The Manhattan College ATLAS group played a key role in dedicated studies and measurements of the Higgs boson properties being members of many analysis teams. One of the obligations of the MC group was to generate and validate Monte Carlo samples for the ATLAS Higgs working groups. Our group developed, implemented and upgraded statistical tools for data analysis. It was found that measured properties of the Higgs boson were compatible with the Standard Model of elementary particles. 

The Standard Model is amazingly successful but there are obvious flaws in the Standard Model. It does not include gravity and cannot explain a significant asymmetry between matter and antimatter in the universe. The Standard Model cannot account for the dark matter and dark energy that make about 95% of the universe. It does not explain tiny but non-zero neutrino mass and has some theoretical problems. It looks like physics beyond the Standard Model is required to resolve these difficulties. 

In 2015, after the LHC upgrade, we entered a new era in particle physics by measuring with high precision the properties of the Higgs boson and searching for physics beyond the Standard Model. A broad Higgs boson physics program has been proposed for LHC Run II. The Manhattan College group contributed to cross section measurements, searches for Higgs bosons beyond the Standard Model, measurements of the Higgs boson couplings at the 10% level and obtained constraints on parameters of effective field theories from the LHC measurements. The MC group worked on the ATLAS collaboration proposal for the high luminosity HL-LHC. The HL-LHC is expected to be completed and operational around 2026. It will open an era of high precision Higgs boson physics. For ATLAS experiment, this enables unprecedented sensitivity for a large range of Higgs boson property measurements, as well as for searches for new particles or additional decay modes. For the HL-LHC our group developed an approach improving the separation of the signal and background in measurements of the Higgs boson properties. 

Our group made a significant contribution to the service work providing the control of the safety and performance of the infrastructure of the ATLAS experimental area facilities. Our students contributed to development, optimization and upgrade of the Transition Radiation Tracker and ATLAS muon system. 

One of the main purposes of this project was to involve undergraduates in research activities and we can conclude that the project provided an excellent opportunity for our physics majors to be actively engaged in cutting-edge research working alongside the world's leading scientists. Our students made real contribution to ATLAS analysis, experimental and service work. They gave presentations at different levels, including international and national conferences, contributed to articles and talks presented at CERN working groups meetings and workshops, and published articles in leading research journals. In Manhattan College we began to publish a journal "The Manhattan Scientist" dedicated to the research of our undergraduate students. This research experience influenced the students' career path and almost all of them either continued their education in graduate study programs or found an employment in the STEM sector.  

A majority of students in the Bronx area, where MC is located, are from under-represented groups.An outreach program in the form of 20 special sessions a year was organized in MC for these high school students. About 100 students of which 75% female regularly attended these sessions. Participation in this program developed the confidence of students, showed them that college and a career in science is a true possibility, and helped them continue their science education. We received "thank you" letters from school guidance counselors for giving their students "the wonderful opportunity" of studying at MC.

This proposal represented an initial attempt to establish a research program on the ATLAS experiment at Manhattan College. Though our proposed plans may seemed ambitious our group managed to accomplish more than we had originally projected and we believe that the results demonstrate that it is possible to make a significant contribution to the top scientific experiments at an undergraduate college level while also contributing to education general level. From 2014 to 2019 with the help of this NSF award we could support research and education of 9 physics majors, 4 education majors and about 100 high school students mostly from the Bronx area participating in the outreach program.
